I am appalled by the cruelty the Trump Administration has demonstrated over the past 24 hours. By indefinitely suspending the Syrian refugee program and imposing a religious test at our borders, he has defied everything our nation stands for. He's also weakened our national security by empowering ISIL's narrative that the West is at war with Islam and encouraging the listed countries to further cooperate with adversaries like Russia and Iran. For decades, America has acted as the Good Samaritan and extended a welcoming hand to those who yearn to be free. We should continue to thoroughly vet all refugees who enter the United States, but we cannot abandon our core principles. If we turn our backs on widows and orphans fleeing the very evil we despise, we do not defeat our enemies; we surrender to them.  It is also incredulous that at the same time the President is asking the Pentagon for new options to defeat ISIL, he is banning Iraqi refugees from entering the country. The government of Iraq is our ally in the fight against ISIL. Its troops fight alongside ours. Its interpreters risk their own lives and the lives of their families to protect U.S. personnel. It undermines our national security and endangers our soldiers to have our Iraqi partners and other Muslim countries distrust our commitment and motives. President Trump said he was ‘totally against’ the U.S. invasion in 2003, which led to Iraq’s destabilization and the rise of ISIL. I guess he is not ‘totally against’ leaving its people to suffer the consequences.

While speaking against the nomination of Sen. Jeff Sessions to be Attorney General, I wanted to share the story of Richard and Mildred Loving, an interracial couple from Virginia who challenged a Virginia law that barred marriages like theirs all the way to the Supreme Court. The Court’s decision ultimately invalidated laws banning interracial marriage. The Lovings were represented by the ACLU Nationwide thanks in part to the referral of then-U.S. Attorney General Robert Kennedy, who demonstrated a commitment to helping the oppressed, especially on matters of civil rights. My point: the poor and the oppressed, those who don’t have anyone else to stand up for them, they need a justice system that will treat them fairly. And the Attorney General must embody that value.

A member of my staff traveled to the Appalachian African American Cultural Center's celebration of Black History Month. The Center did a fantastic job of highlighting the stories of people in the region that have contributed to the region's rich history. In the picture below, Ron Carson shares the story of his great grandmother, Rachel Scott, who used her savings from her barbershop in 1939 to build the only primary school for African Americans in all of Lee County. Up until that time, African American children were being taught in the basement of an abandoned church. This is just one of countless stories that form our history and teach us lessons for the future.

I am saddened and outraged by the recent rise of anti-Semitic incidents across our nation, including vandalism of Jewish cemeteries and bomb threats targeting Jewish community centers and day schools. Just yesterday, the Gesher Jewish Day School in Fairfax County was the target of a bomb threat, one of 31 similar incidents targeting Jewish centers and schools across the nation in a single day. There is nothing more cowardly than targeting institutions where our children go to learn and thrive. I want to express my deep solidarity and support to America’s Jewish community and to all who are victims of hateful threats and actions. I strongly condemn these terrifying incidents, which must be rejected.  It is no coincidence that we are witnessing a rise in hate speech and crimes targeting minority groups in America, including more than 100 bomb threats against Jewish entities since the beginning of this year and a 67% increase in hate crimes against Muslims in 2015. Divisive political rhetoric has sadly contributed to a climate where individuals who espouse hate feel emboldened.    The Administration must speak out clearly, consistently, and forcefully against the rising tide of anti-Semitism and hate crimes impacting communities across our nation. But words are not enough. I urge the Administration to outline to Congress and to the American people how it plans to respond to this threat, including bringing to justice the individuals or groups behind these incidents, and taking the necessary steps to effectively deter these threats in the future.

This is directly relevant to Virginia, given the Navy’s nuclear powered aircraft carriers and submarines constructed and stationed in Hampton Roads as well as the BWXT Nuclear Operations Group manufacturing facility in Lynchburg. Governor Perry was apparently unaware until his nomination that nuclear security comprises much of what the Department of Energy does. That conveys to me not only a lack of expertise in a critical national security area but a lack of seriousness and appreciation for this responsibility.

Disappointed Republicans on the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee scheduled a hearing today on off-topic policy issues as opposed to letting us debate TrumpCare. They are silencing debate by bypassing Senate hearings, which prevents the American public from learning about the details of the bill that the CBO found would take health care away from 24 million people by 2026. Patients and families across the country and Virginia deserve to know more about the devastating impact it would have.

It’s clear there is little support for TrumpCare, a bill that takes away health care from 24 million Americans, makes older Americans face higher premiums, burdens states with dramatic Medicaid cuts, and deprives women of access and coverage. And all of this to deliver what amounts to a tax break for the wealthiest Americans at the expense of middle class families and seniors.     I doubt that the vote on TrumpCare would have been pulled down if not for hundreds of thousands of Americans going to town hall meetings, calling their members of Congress, writing letters, and holding marches. I applaud the energetic activism of the American people.   The reality is that more American families still want improvements to the current health care system and we shouldn't give up on making reforms. As a member of the Senate HELP Committee, I look forward to bipartisan dialogue to enhance coverage, quality, and affordability.

100 years ago as leaders in the United States grappled with the decision to enter World War I, U.S. leaders put partisan politics aside and took their roles and responsibilities seriously. President Wilson delivered his War Address to Congress on April 2, 1917 and by April 6 both bodies of Congress approved a declaration of war against Imperial Germany. Congress did not declare war out of a desire to send nearly five million U.S. servicemembers overseas and over 116,000 to give the ultimate sacrifice, but rather they did this because it was their solemn duty outlined in the Constitution that sending servicemembers overseas to fight for their country deserves a public debate and decision by their elected representatives. We must always have an eye to the past as we consider our approach to current events. I’m proud to cosponsor this resolution commemorating the U.S. entry into WWI 100 years ago today. Over 100,000 Virginians served in WWI and over 4,000 died in or in support of it. These sacrifices were made to advance a more democratic and stable world.

A year and six months into my term as Governor, Anne and I had just arrived in Tokyo to lead a delegation of Virginia business leaders on an overseas trade mission. We ate dinner and turned in after a long flight only to be awakened around midnight with word that there was an active shooting underway back home.  We turned on CNN and quickly decided to return on the next flight home.   Jet-lagged and grief-stricken we arrived in Washington and then flew with President George W. Bush and the First Lady to Blacksburg to meet with families and address a community gathering the day after the shooting.   We shed tears with families of students and faculty members who had lost their lives. We gathered with thousands of Hokies--and we were all Hokies--to mourn and to celebrate the lives of the precious people who were killed. Anne and I went to visit those recovering in nearby hospitals. We thanked brave first responders who had seen the unforgettable horror of classrooms filled with bullet-riddled bodies, many with ringing cell phones in their pockets as frantic family members tried to reach them.   In the days that followed, I decided to form a panel of experts to investigate everything that happened that day and issue a complete public report outlining what went wrong. The report was unsparing and comprehensive. It led Virginia to make some changes in mental health and privacy laws. It inspired changes in campus safety protocols around the nation that are still used today. We learned that a flaw in our background records check system had allowed the killer to purchase a weapon even though he was legally barred from doing so due to a court judgment that he was mentally ill and dangerous. I was able to make a partial fix to our system via executive order but efforts to create a truly comprehensive background check system have failed in Virginia and Congress again and again.   That time created a bond with so many of the Virginia Tech families. I continue to be in awe of their strength and resilience, and I cherish their continued friendship all these years later. Today, on the tenth anniversary of the tragedy and on Easter Sunday, we remember the victims, survivors and heroes. #VTWeRemember

Faith from Herndon wrote to me about her superhero daughter, Ana. Stories like these are why we can’t repeal the Affordable Care Act, replace it with Trumpcare, and dismantle the Medicaid program like the Graham-Cassidy proposal does.   “Ana is currently 4, though she will very excitedly tell you that she's about to be 5 on October 1st. She makes friends literally everywhere we go. Ana loves all things princess, dance and music (singing or playing instruments), animals, drawing/painting, and adventuring. She adamantly wants to be a veterinarian one day.   “Ana's medical diagnosis - congenital heart defects including: HRHS (Hypoplastic Right Heart Syndrome), transposition of arteries, VSD) - means that she is missing the right ventricle from her heart. She underwent 4 major open heart surgeries as well as numerous less-invasive procedures. Her blood flow was corrected so that her heart can now pump oxygen throughout her body sufficiently as she grows. Without these procedures, she would not have lived more than a week. While she looks and acts normal from the outside, she will always have only 1/2 a heart and will always carry the risk of requiring a transplant later on in life.    “As a single mom going through grad school, I am fortunate to have employer-based healthcare at this time. But, beyond grad school, I am looking to venture out on my own into my own practice eventually in the medical service industry (behavior therapist/analyst), and there is a very real possibility that I will either have to rely on exchange-based healthcare or provide my own as a self-employed individual. Without the ACA, these probabilities become extremely daunting and could possibly stall my ability to change careers and chase these dreams. Beyond my own ambitions, without the ACA Ana runs the risk of either hitting her lifetime cap before she even becomes an adult, or having to choose between healthcare/future procedures/living and chasing her own dreams (college, life events). No child should have to choose between living and fulfilling their own ambitions."

IAEA was right and U.S. started an unnecessary war.  2) Starting the process to walk away from a deal that the IAEA and the President's own national security team says is working could lead Iran to step away. Bottom line — President Trump decertifying the deal, over objections of his national security team, IAEA and our allies, weakens diplomacy and raises the risk of war.
